text: what I find
particularly upsetting um is not just
what's happening to people who have been
working their whole lives in the Auto
industry but also that the United Auto
Workers you know founded by the Ruther
Brothers to me were kind of like the you
know the the Harvard and Yale of the
labor union movement and it's really a
testament to them that Auto Workers were
able to work and have careers and really
be middle class and really do well and
you know in the middle of all of this
situation in our whole economy is
essentially this view that there's
something in that that's not workable
and I think some pieces of that may very
well not be workable and some pieces of
that I think um are showing what what
the next phase of our economy is going
to look like and by that I
mean if you look at Detroit as one of
our large economic centers in this
country you had a whole group of people
who could afford a lot of things and
paid a lot of taxes and supported a
whole lot of other Industries all
brought to you in large part by the
United Auto Workers and so we have to be
careful that we don't you know kill the
patient uh by curing you know one one
piece of this this problem uh so I think
it is a good thing that the uh Obama
administration is recognizing that this
is really nuanced this isn't just about
fixing the Auto industry per se but that
it's a whole ecosystem and system
together of course I wish I had like a
very short and piy answer to that but
you know my hunch is that because this
is called like big think Big Ideas um
that we're realizing that you can't
expect a certain rate of return uh on
manufacturing and the Auto industry and
expect to have one in America that is
that we can't have private Equity rates
of Return of 18 to 35% and that we're
going to have to be thinking that
there's something important about having
certain industries and there's going to
be a governmental role in keeping these
alive it's crucial that we make things
in America and um I think this is the
beginning of of that realization I think
that people are starting to see there's
something important here I think
sometimes people think this is just
about bailing out the Auto industry you
know beginning middle and end and done I
think hopefully there are people who are
saying wow there's something deeper here
that we need to understand that
government can be a source of capital or
can subsidize some parts of capital or
can bear some piece of the risk because
we recognize that it's really important
to have a middle class in America and I
think that's really what's at stake you
know we may very well come out of this
but the question is are we going to come
out of it looking you know like uh
Argentina you know with a very small
group of rich people and a very large
group of everybody else and I don't
think that's what America is
about I just think that's just factually
wrong if you say that there are elements
in terms of the costs of health and
pensions which I think is true um then
that's a piece of it you know it's also
a piece of not having a government
strategy that says we don't care that
Americans may very well when ask say
they want the biggest Behemoth cars and
you know that they can get their hands
on but that's not why we have government
leaders and that you know one of the
reasons why people want bigger cars is
because other people have big cars and
it's not just because they're pigs you
know I I have a child and I know that
when I go out and I want to make sure
she's okay and when kids are very young
you have to make sure that the airbags
are one thing and another thing and
having everybody having SUVs is just
like a big arms race and government has
to start saying that that's not
acceptable and those are the kinds of
things that I think we need to to do is
to start to having some public policy
about what's acceptable what isn't
acceptable if you're still going to go
out and need to have a big hulking
automobile you should be paying a lot of
extra fees associated with that you know
I think we need to be looking at the
incentives and the
disincentives no I really feel bad
because 20 million just doesn't buy what
it used to but um you know and what I
think is more profound I think it's
really easy to just be angry at all
these CEOs you know we're so angry at
them and they live in Greenwich
Connecticut and blah blah blah but we
set up the rules of the game and when I
say we I mean like the citizens allowed
this to happen over the last 25 years
that we said the job of any good CEO is
to get maximum return on investment
period it doesn't matter sort of how
they do it and if any of them show
restraint then we're going to punish
them and you saw that that happened with
the CEO of Home Depot who you know now
looks like a genius but you know in the
last five or seven years he said I think
it's important to pay people wages that
uh you know are good solid wages with
benefits and there's been a whole debate
about with is that okay cuz was he
maximizing shareholder returns so I
think that we really have to stop and
say did we set up the rules of the game
so that these people just played it that
way and then I think having said that
and I think that really is the bulk of
it I think that we as a society have to
hold ourselves responsible for certain
things and that part of that is that we
really believe that was in our right
to really use up the Earth's resources
in a way and be very wealthy and have
state-of-the-art kitchens and fancy
things and these corporate CEOs were
just the worst of it you know but it's
something that I think we see all over
the place and I think it's a culture of
greed that I I think is bad
